etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in Morte Arthure. From Anglo-Norman alette, specific use of alette little wing from ale wing + -ete

definitions: Each of a pair of pieces of leather or other material worn over the shoulders as part of the accoutrements of an armoured knight or man-at-arms.

notes.text: Now generally thought to have been worn primarily for purposes of heraldic display or other decoration rather than for protection.
